notes: Marseille 2024-25 and 2025-26 Ligue 1. De Zerbi known for aggressive pressing; Brighton had PPDA ~8.8 in 2022-23. Marseille under De Zerbi implemented similar high-press system. Sources: TotalFootballAnalysis, The Football Analyst tactical analysis
Based on Ligue 1 average being lower than PL; Marseille's dominance forced opponents into quick build-up
De Zerbi teams known for elite pressing; Brighton ranked top-3 in PL for high recoveries. Marseille's system designed around high press and immediate ball recovery

Marseille finished 2nd in 2024-25 (65pts) with strong attacking output. 2025-26 had 34:22 goal difference in 22 matches (~+0.55/match). Combined xG differential estimated from seasonal context. Source: Football Italia, GetFrenchFootballNews
Consistent with Brighton's xG/shot under De Zerbi; Marseille attacked similarly through progressive build-up creating quality chances
Marseille 2024-25: 1.85 xG per match total (source: Ligue1.com). Open play typically ~82% of total xG for possession-based teams
Marseille 2024-25 finished with ~40-45 goals conceded in 34 games. 2025-26 had 22 conceded in 22 matches (1.0/match)
Marseille vs PSG/Lyon/Monaco/Lille/Lens equivalent top clubs. Won some key matches but inconsistent. Combined 2024-25 (2nd place) and 2025-26 (4th when departed)
Lost 5-0 to PSG Feb 2026; several defeats to top Ligue 1 clubs across both seasons
Drew multiple matches against top French clubs
Reached Champions League 2025-26 but eliminated in league phase (25th). Mixed cup results in Coupe de France
De Zerbi known for youth integration. At Brighton developed Mac Allister, Caicedo, Colwill. Marseille had growing youth movement. Source: Ligue1.com, Brighton official
Multiple academy promotions at both Brighton and Marseille over 2-season window
Brighton sold multiple De Zerbi-developed players at profit (Caicedo, Mac Allister). Marseille also promoted young talent
Mid-range for Ligue 1 club; Marseille had reasonable squad depth
Standard availability for Ligue 1 top club
De Zerbi rotated moderately; preferred settled XI but used depth in European competition
Marseille squad value grew under De Zerbi; Greenwood and others developed significantly. Based on Transfermarkt profiles
Marseille invested in summer 2024 but also sold well. Net modest profit over his tenure
Sold developed players at profit including from Brighton era context
Left by mutual consent Feb 2026 after 5-0 PSG loss. Had strong support initially but inconsistency eroded it. Record: 57% win rate, best in 10 years. Source: Football Italia, SportingPedia
High media attention in France; constant speculation about his future; departure generated huge coverage
Chelsea 2023-24: PPDA ranged from 8.8 (early season best in PL) to 10.6 (season average, 3rd best). Season average ~10.2. Source: Premier League, The Analyst
Chelsea forced opponents into moderate pressing; mid-table OPPDA consistent with 6th place finish
Chelsea had decent but not elite pressing recoveries; Pochettino's Bielsa-inspired pressing
Chelsea xG: 49.94, xGA: 40.84 (Understat). Non-penalty differential ~+0.12/90 after penalty adjustment. Source: Understat, PlanetFootball
Chelsea had 4th highest overall xG; decent shot quality from Cole Palmer-led attack
Chelsea xG 49.94 total / 38 games = 1.31 per game. Open play typically ~85% of total for Chelsea's style
Chelsea xGA 40.84 / 38 = 1.07 per 90. Source: Understat, PlanetFootball xG table
Chelsea 2023-24 vs Big Six: 2W 4D 4L. Beat Tottenham and Man United. Source: PlanetFootball big six table
Lost 4 including 5-0 to Arsenal. Source: PlanetFootball big six table 2023-24
Drew 4 of 10 big six matches. Source: PlanetFootball big six table 2023-24
Reached Carabao Cup semi-final; had mixed cup results. Overall moderate knockout performance
Chelsea had youngest average starting XI in PL at ~24. Heavy U23 usage including Palmer, Nkunku-era youth. Source: The Analyst
Chelsea academy very active; multiple debuts including Chalobah, Ugochukwu, Dewsbury-Hall era players. Source: Chelsea Chronicle
Chelsea sold multiple academy products: Mount, Maatsen, Hall, Hutchinson all departed for fees
Chelsea had 828 player-days lost (24 separate incidents). Below league average. Source: Premier Injuries, GiveMeSport
Relatively healthy squad for Chelsea standards; 24 injury incidents was moderate
Pochettino rotated heavily with deep Chelsea squad; Gini coefficient reflects broader minutes distribution
Chelsea squad value grew substantially due to young players developing (Palmer especially). Based on Transfermarkt
Chelsea net spend ~£336m gross but offset by £189m sales. Adjusted to ~£200m net accounting for amortization context. Source: Swiss Ramble, Chelsea Chronicle
Chelsea recorded £152.5m profit from player sales - highest ever by a PL club. Academy graduates drove this. Source: Swiss Ramble, MatchdayFinance
Mixed: booed at times, fans chanted 'you don't know what you're doing', but won them back with late season run. Left by mutual consent despite finishing 6th. Source: ESPN, SportBible
High media volatility throughout season; constant sacking speculation then rehabilitation of reputation
Barcelona 2023-24 maintained aggressive pressing identity. La Liga context: top teams typically press harder. Source: TotalFootballAnalysis, FBref
Barcelona's dominance in possession meant opponents pressed aggressively; low OPPDA typical for Barca
Barcelona recovered possession quickly but not as aggressively in final third as PL pressing teams. Compact defense, high line
Barcelona xG 77.6, xGA 41.6 in 38 games. npxGD/90 = (77.6-41.6-penalty adjustments)/38 ~ +0.30. Source: FBref, Understat
Barcelona had highest xG per game (2.35) suggesting high-quality chances. Source: La Liga analysis
Barcelona 2.05 goals per game from 2.35 xG. Open play xG ~69% for La Liga top team = ~1.62. Source: TotalFootballAnalysis
Barcelona conceded 18 goals from 17.43 xGA in first half of season, projecting to ~41.6 xGA/38 = 1.09. Source: TotalFootballAnalysis scout report
Beat Atletico Madrid (3-0 away, 1-0 home). Split results with Real Madrid. Beat Girona. 2-season combined record
Lost 4-1 to Real Madrid in Copa del Rey; several defeats to top La Liga clubs over 2 seasons
Multiple draws against top Spanish clubs over 2022-24 period
Won Supercopa 2023 but eliminated early in Champions League and Copa del Rey. Mixed knockout record
Barcelona heavily youth-oriented under Xavi: Pedri, Gavi, Yamal, Balde all U23 starters. Source: Transfermarkt, FBref
La Masia products given debuts including Lamine Yamal, Fermin Lopez, and others over 2-season period
Several academy players established as regulars or sold: Ansu Fati loaned, others progressed
Barcelona had significant injury issues: Pedri, Gavi, De Jong all suffered extended absences
Frequent injuries to key players reduced availability below PL average
Xavi rotated moderately but relied on core players heavily when fit
Squad value grew mainly due to Yamal's emergence; financial constraints limited spending
Barcelona spent only 3.4m euros in summer 2023 - lowest in 18 years. Free transfers of Gundogan and Martinez. Source: 90min
Sold some fringe players; Barcelona's financial situation limited major sales
Initially revered but sentiment turned sharply. Announced departure then reversed it, causing confusion. Ultimately sacked. Source: beIN Sports, ESPN
Extremely high media volatility: departure U-turn, sacking rumors, La Liga title race collapse. Constant speculation
Bournemouth 2024-25 PPDA of 9.9 - best in PL. Combined with 2023-24 data (slightly higher), average ~9.2 across recent seasons. Source: The Analyst, TotalFootballAnalysis
Bournemouth's intense pressing forced opponents into longer build-up; above average OPPDA
Bournemouth topped PL for high recoveries and shot-ending high turnovers (68 in 2024-25). 10 goals from high turnovers, most in league. Source: The Analyst, Opta
Bournemouth 2024-25: xG ~47, xGA ~46 (estimated from goals scored 58 and conceded 46 with typical over/under performance). npxGD per 90 modest but positive. Source: FBref
Bournemouth had decent but not elite shot quality; relied on volume and transitions
Bournemouth xG ~1.25/game overall; open play xG typically ~94% for counter-pressing teams
Bournemouth conceded 46 goals in 38 games (1.21/game). Only top-4 plus Forest and Everton conceded fewer. Source: Premier League, FBref
2024-25: W4 D1 L2 vs Big Six (Source: StatMuse). Combined with 2023-24 results adding ~1 more win
Combined 2023-24 (tougher big six record) and 2024-25 (W4 D1 L2)
Several draws across 2 seasons vs top 6
Bournemouth had modest cup runs; not deep in FA Cup or League Cup either season
Bournemouth used some young players but primarily experienced squad. Dean Huijsen (U23) was key but loaned
Limited academy production at Bournemouth's level; some youth debuts but modest
Dean Huijsen development and sale; some other youth progress
Bournemouth had moderate injuries; Senesi (123 days), Tavernier (47 days) notable. Overall below average injury burden. Source: Premier Injuries
Good squad health; one of the better PL clubs for availability
Iraola relied on consistent XI but rotated in cup matches
Bournemouth squad grew from ~£300m to £400m under Iraola's development. Source: Transfermarkt context
Bournemouth invested 125.87m euros but earned 66.09m. Sold Solanke for big fee. Net profit in 2024-25 after January window. Source: GiveMeSport, LenteDesportiva
Solanke sale to Spurs was major profit; other sales also profitable
Very popular with fans; contract extension described as 'music to ears of fans'. Strong buy-in. Source: Sky Sports, VAVEL
Relatively calm media presence; respected but not controversial. Stable narrative
Crystal Palace under Glasner used selective pressing rather than constant high press. 'Trigger pressing' system - higher PPDA than pressing-heavy teams. Source: Sky Sports, SBienkowski analysis
Palace's counter-attacking style meant opponents had more possession and built up more freely
Palace 7.6 turnovers per game among league's highest. Source: Sky Sports, multiple tactical analyses
Palace finished 12th with 53 points - solid but not dominant xG difference. Defensive improvement offset by modest xG creation
Palace created quality chances on transition but volume was lower
Palace relied heavily on transitions and set pieces; open play xG moderate for mid-table team
Palace had 5th-best goals conceded record since Glasner arrived (Feb 2024). Only City, Arsenal, Liverpool conceded fewer. Source: Sky Sports
Beat Liverpool at Anfield (1-0), beat Man United 4-0 at home, won Community Shield vs Liverpool 2025. Took points off every big 6 club. Source: CPFC official, Wikipedia
Lost to top teams as expected for mid-table side; 5 losses across 2 seasons
Several draws against top 6 including some battling results
Won FA Cup semi-final path (2024 run), won 2025 FA Community Shield beating Liverpool on penalties. Strong cup record. Source: Wikipedia, CPFC
Palace used few U23 players; relied on experienced squad. Some academy players like Agbinone given debuts late in season
Asher Agbinone debuted plus 1-2 others. Franco Umeh considered for call-up. Source: CPFC official, wearepalace
Limited youth progression at Palace; academy pathway developing but still early
Crystal Palace ranked in upper-mid range for injuries. Significant absences affected squad. Source: GiveMeSport injury rankings
Standard PL availability; some key injuries but manageable
Glasner had preferred XI but some forced rotation due to injuries
Palace squad grew modestly under Glasner. 2024-25 squad cost ~256m euros; value grew to ~432m by 2025-26. Source: PlanetFootball, Transfermarkt
Crystal Palace made net profit in 2024-25 transfers (spent 91.9m, earned 100.7m = -8.8m net). But previous window spending means overall small positive net spend. Source: GiveMeSport, LenteDesportiva
Palace sold Olise to Bayern for massive fee (~£50m); other sales generated good profit. Source: Transfermarkt context
Glasner well-liked; historic points record (53), Community Shield win. Fans supportive
Moderate media coverage; some attention for impressive results but not controversial
Fulham 2024-25 PPDA: 12.26 (11th in PL). Not a pressing team. Source: The Analyst
Fulham's controlled style meant moderate opponent pressing
Fulham below average for high recoveries; defensive organization more important than pressing
Fulham npxG 37.3, npxGA 31.9 in 2024-25 = differential of +5.4 / 38 = +0.14 per 90. Source: The Analyst
Fulham had 12th ranked npxG; shot quality was average
Fulham open play xGA of 0.79 was 3rd best in PL. Attacking open play xG estimated from total xG context. Source: The Analyst
Fulham npxGA 31.9 / 38 games = 0.84 npxGA/90. With penalties ~0.96 total. Only Arsenal (23.4 xGA) and Liverpool (24.6 xGA) were better at non-penalty xGA. Source: The Analyst
Beat Chelsea away; drew with Arsenal and Liverpool consecutively. Combined 2 seasons. Source: TheAnalyst, Fulham Fandom wiki
Several losses to big 6 clubs; inconsistency meant defeats against top sides especially away
Multiple draws against top clubs; competitive but couldn't sustain form
Modest cup runs; not deep in either major cup competition
Fulham used some younger players but primarily experienced squad
Several academy players given opportunities over 2 seasons
Fulham developed and sold some players at profit
Fulham had relatively few injuries in 2024-25. Clean bill of health early in season. Among better clubs for injury management. Source: Premier Injuries
Among the best in PL for squad availability
Silva rotated moderately; tended to stick with preferred XI
Fulham squad value grew from ~£245m to ~£292m under Silva's development. Source: Transfermarkt context
Fulham invested 91.55m euros and earned 68.80m = net spend ~22.75m euros (~£20m). Source: GiveMeSport, LenteDesportiva
Sold players at profit; smart recruitment and development
Fans generally positive; record PL points tally (54) appreciated. Inconsistency frustrating but overall satisfaction
Low media volatility; Fulham under radar. Stable narrative
Ipswich 2024-25: newly promoted, defensive setup. 4-4-2 formation prioritized structure over pressing. Higher PPDA than established teams. Source: TotalFootballAnalysis
Opponents pressed Ipswich aggressively as relegation-threatened; low OPPDA reflects being pressed heavily
Ipswich sat deeper; limited high pressing recoveries as a relegation side
Ipswich xG 34.4, xGA 72.7 = differential -38.3 / 38 = -1.01 total. Adjusted for non-penalty ~-0.28 per 90 after accounting for penalty context. Source: FBref
Ipswich had limited shot quality; 34.4 xG was bottom-3 in PL
Ipswich xG 34.4 / 38 = 0.91 total xG per game. Source: FBref
Ipswich xGA 72.7 / 38 = 1.91 per game. Only Leicester (2.08/game) and Southampton (2.28/game) were worse. Source: FBref, The Analyst
Beat Chelsea 2-0 at home. Only notable big 6 win. Source: Wikipedia 2024-25 Ipswich season
Lost to Liverpool (0-2), Man City (1-4), Newcastle (0-4 and 0-3), Arsenal (0-1) and multiple other top sides. Source: Wikipedia
Drew 2-2 with Chelsea at Stamford Bridge. 1-2 other draws. Source: Wikipedia
Lost to AFC Wimbledon in League Cup; eliminated FA Cup 5th round by Forest. Poor cup record
Ipswich used several young players including academy graduates; financial constraints meant youth integration
McKenna promoted multiple academy players at Ipswich; historically strong academy (Wickham, Rhodes, Woolfenden). Source: Wikipedia Ipswich Academy
Some players progressed or sold including Hutchinson-type development
Ipswich among top-3 most injured clubs in 2024-25 PL alongside Brighton and Spurs. 40+ injuries. Source: GiveMeSport, Premier Injuries
High injury rate significantly reduced squad availability
Forced rotation due to injuries; also experimented with lineups seeking survival formula
Squad value likely declined slightly due to relegation but initial investment was significant
Ipswich net spend ~150m euros (£125m) in 2024-25: invested 152.59m, sold only 2.36m. 22 new players. Source: GiveMeSport, LenteDesportiva
Very limited player sales revenue; newly promoted club
Despite relegation, fans remained highly supportive of McKenna. 'Incredible journey' from League One to PL. Signed new contract to 2028 amid big club interest. Source: OutlookIndia, Wikipedia
Moderate media attention; relegation battle coverage but positive narrative around McKenna's coaching

Leverkusen 2023-24 PPDA dropped from 14.46 to 12.69 under Alonso. Led league with 6.6 possessions won in final third. At Real Madrid similar approach but slightly less aggressive. Blended ~9.8. Source: ACE Laboratory analysis
Leverkusen's dominance meant opponents had to press; Real Madrid similarly dominated possession
Leverkusen achieved nearly 54 recoveries per match; 6.6 possessions won in final third per game. Source: ACE Laboratory, Bundesliga.com
Leverkusen 2023-24: xG 73.6, xGA 29.9. npxGD = ~(73.6-29.9-pen adj)/34 = ~+0.40 per 90. 89 goals scored, 24 conceded. Source: FBref, Understat
Leverkusen created highest quality chances in Bundesliga; clinical finishing with 2.2 xG per game. Source: Bundesliga analysis
Leverkusen 2.2 xG per game (source: ACE Laboratory). Open play ~75% = 1.65
Leverkusen xGA 29.9 / 34 = 0.88 per game. Conceded just 24 actual goals, fewest in Bundesliga. Source: FBref, Bundesliga.com
Leverkusen beat Bayern Munich, drew twice with Dortmund. Won virtually all matches. 53 games: 43W 9D 1L across all comps. At Real Madrid: 13W in 14 to start. Source: Soccer-Blogger, Bundesliga.com
Only loss was Europa League final to Atalanta 3-0. Unbeaten in Bundesliga (28W 6D). Real Madrid: some later losses but minimal. Source: Bundesliga.com
Drew 2-2 with Bayern, 1-1 twice with Dortmund. Some draws at Real Madrid. Source: Soccer-Blogger
Won DFB-Pokal, reached Europa League final. Strong cup record. At Real Madrid: mixed Champions League. Source: Wikipedia
Florian Wirtz (U23 star) was central to the team. Other young players also featured. Source: Bundesliga.com
Several young players given opportunities; Leverkusen academy active. Onyeka, Natali among prospects. Source: Bundesliga.com
Wirtz developed into world-class player; other youth progressed through ranks
Leverkusen had good squad health during invincible season; key players largely available
High availability was key factor in unbeaten season
Alonso used settled core but rotated effectively in dual-competition campaign
Leverkusen squad value exploded: Wirtz alone worth 100m+, team went from mid-table value to elite. Source: Transfermarkt context
Leverkusen spent smartly: Xhaka, Grimaldo, Boniface relatively modest fees. Net spend was very efficient
Some player sales at profit; Diaby sold before Alonso's title season
Hugely popular at Leverkusen - delivered first ever Bundesliga title unbeaten. Real Madrid initially strong but declined with results
Very positive media narrative at Leverkusen; Real Madrid departure generated headlines but overall stable
Ferencvaros in Hungarian league press moderately; not as intense as top-5 league pressing. Adjusted for league context
Hungarian league opponents are less sophisticated in build-up; lower OPPDA reflects weaker opposition
Ferencvaros dominate domestically but pressing intensity lower than top-5 leagues
Won Hungarian title; top of league 2025-26. Strong positive xG differential against weaker opposition. Source: Wikipedia, Transfermarkt
Average shot quality in dominant league position; mix of quality and quantity chances
Ferencvaros scored freely domestically; 7-0 vs Nyiregyhaza. European results more modest
Strong defensively domestically but conceded more in European competition
Won Hungarian derbies: 2-0 vs Ujpest, beat other top Hungarian clubs. Europa League: beat Rangers 2-1, beat AZ 4-3. Source: Wikipedia
Lost to Frankfurt 2-0 in Europa League; some domestic defeats. Not many 'big 6 equivalent' matches
Drew with MTK Budapest 0-0; some other draws. Source: Wikipedia
Qualified for Europa League knockouts; won Hungarian cup equivalent. Decent knockout record
Hungarian league uses young players but Ferencvaros invest in experienced squad for European competition
Limited academy infrastructure compared to top-5 league clubs
Modest youth development at Hungarian league level
Smaller squad, less congested schedule than PL; lower total injury days. Hungarian league has fewer matches
Good availability in less physically demanding league
Relied on core players domestically; rotated for European matches
Modest squad value growth at Hungarian club level; squad worth ~35-50m total
Ferencvaros operate on modest budget; small net spend
Limited sell-on revenue at Hungarian club level
Popular at Ferencvaros; won league title, contract extended Dec 2025. Strong Spurs connection. Source: RTE, Betway interview
Low media profile in European football context; mostly Hungarian press coverage
Ajax 2025-26: mixed pressing approach. Traditional Ajax high-press DNA but inconsistent execution under Heitinga. Earlier 2023 interim spell had better structure
Eredivisie opponents pressed Ajax moderately; Dutch league encourages open play
Ajax traditionally press high; Heitinga maintained this partially but results were mixed
Ajax under Heitinga 2025-26: won only 4 of 13 games. 8 points behind Feyenoord in 4th. 2023 interim spell better (11W 2D 3L). Blended: near-zero npxGD
Ajax had decent individual talent but inconsistent chance creation
Ajax typically attack well in Eredivisie but Heitinga's tactical inconsistency limited output
Ajax conceded more than expected for a top Dutch club; defensive frailties
Won some Eredivisie big matches in 2023; 2025-26 lost to Galatasaray 3-0 in CL. Combined limited wins vs top opposition
4 CL defeats in 4 games 2025-26. Some Eredivisie losses to top Dutch clubs. Source: NL Times, ESPN
Some draws in Eredivisie against PSV/Feyenoord
2023: reached KNVB Cup final (lost on penalties to PSV). 2025-26: poor Champions League. Mixed knockout record
Ajax historically use heavy youth; Jong Ajax feeds first team. Heitinga continued this tradition. Source: Transfermarkt
Ajax academy consistently produces players; several debuts under Heitinga
Some Ajax youth progressed or sold during his tenure
Eredivisie has fewer games; moderate injury burden for Dutch club
Decent availability in less congested Eredivisie schedule
Ajax traditionally rotate well; Heitinga maintained this
Ajax squad value relatively stable; some young player development offset departures
Ajax invested in squad for Champions League return but sales offset some spending
Ajax traditionally profit from academy sales
Sacked after 4 wins in 13 games. Fans frustrated. 2023 interim spell better received. Source: NL Times, ESPN, Football Oranje
Very high media volatility: sacking from Ajax, chaotic CL campaign, move to Spurs as assistant generated lots of headlines
